title: @Rioters since you partnered up with Marvel, I have a question for you guys?
body: Do you have any favourite comic book writers by any chance?

replies.body: I mostly grew up reading manga but i really like: Rucka, mignola, bendis, and kirkman.

They will make story of Wukong x Ahri too?
https://66.media.tumblr.com/c0a57e1b7db0504ac17b3f894ef56471/tumblr_pmya84lbef1qjao5lo1_1280.jpg
What manga you grew up reading?

Mostly all the normal, mainstream stuff, 
Akira, Nausicaa, Ramna 1/2, Inyusha, Battle Angel, Dominion tank police, ghost in the shell, Appleseed, barefoot gen.   I’m old enough that that stuff was kinda just getting realsed in the usa for the first time, when i was an early teen. 

  I also like: one piece, Naruto, and blade of the immortal, but i was in college when i got into them.

The only kinda esoteric thing i loved was “Short Program” by mitsuru adachi..  book 1 is tied with Akira as my favorite.  Just a book of realworld human short stories— but really heartly warming.

I'm 21 years old and have been reading since I was in 5th grade; it's still kind of weird to me that stuff like that used to be the mainstream in the U.S., while nowadays things align way more closely with Japan (i.e. stuff for teenagers is the most popular; Viz media literally publishes Shonen Jump concurrently with Japan which is wild).  Rumiko Takahashi examples aside, of course.

I've had a couple Mitsuru Adachi works in my to read [EDIT: no "too rad" lol] list (mainly because he's a big name in sports stories), but that looks interesting now that I've seen it.  It's going near the top of the list for now.

My brother and me were talking the other day about how poor Marvel comics are at the moment (I say this as I don't know about right now as stopped reading a couple of years back, Hickman and Bendis ruined things), Grant Morrison's X-men era was so good. Mid 2000s comics were just superb, same as the 80 comics, Mark Gruenwalds stuff was great and the 80s dealt with issues I don't think modern Disney Marvel would.

Bendis was super hit or miss for me. He often had good ideas and had dialogue that really worked for certain kinds of characters but that dialogue doesn't work for every comic and he often like... just failed to tell the story. I dunno how else to put it. But that era where he did avengers had a lot of good books at marvel, from a lot of talent that's left now. Remender, Gillen, Fraction usually were all good. Hickman did a really great run on fantastic four too.

Bendis work on Alias and Daredevil was top notch but when he moved to team books, it wasn't the best. His X-men (along side Hickman's Avengers/Secret Wars) is what made me stop reading and I'm finding it hard to get back into X-men after so many years reading them, as things change so much so quickly. I hated the 'Young' X-men, they weren't the O5, Jean was a horrible person. Weirdly I enjoyed his last few issues on Uncanny.

Remender's stuff was okay. Gillen and Fraction always did good stuff. Hickman's Avenger stuff was drivel, read like it was written by a 13 yr old writing fan fiction, "We need to get bigger." repeated over and over. Mike Carey did, superb work.

Now Brian K Vaughan on the other hand, there is a man who can write comics, Ed Brubaker too.
I always find Morrison a coin flip. Either it’s absolutely brilliant, or pretension drivel so far up its own ass.
His writing is always super interesting to me, but whether it works for you def depends on your personal tastes and the specific work. His batman and X-Men were pretty legendary runs though
